content.text: An argument is **valid** if it would be contradictory (impossible) to have the premises all true and conclusion false. Validity doesn't say the premises *are* true, but only that the conclusion follows from them.

content.definition: An argument where, if the premises were all true, then the conclusion would have to be true. The form of the argument guarantees this relationship.

content.title: A Valid Argument (Modus Tollens)
premises: If you overslept, you'll be late.
content.note: This argument is valid because of its form: If A then B, Not-B, therefore Not-A.

content.text: Our argument is valid because of its **logical form**: how it arranges logical notions like 'if-then' and content like 'You overslept.' We can display the form using symbols:

symbols.name: Conditional
symbols.example: If you overslept → you'll be late

content.title: An Invalid Argument (Affirming the Consequent)
premises: If you overslept, you'll be late.
content.note: INVALID! You might be late for another reason (car trouble, traffic, etc.). This fallacy is called 'affirming the consequent.'

content.definition: The abstract structure of an argument, ignoring the specific content. Replacing A and B with other content yields another valid (or invalid) argument of the same form.

content.question: Which argument form is this: 'If A then B. Not B. Therefore, not A.'
content.explanation: This is Modus Tollens - a valid argument form. If the conditional is true and the consequent is false, the antecedent must also be false.
